article_summary:
The average total “tax wedge” is the difference between the gross cost to a company of employing one person and what that worker takes home after income tax and employee and employer social insurance taxes.
That’s the conclusion from the OECD’s latest “Taxing Wages” report, which finds the average worker paid a higher proportion of income in tax in 2014 than in 2010.
Your government hopes you haven’t noticed, but if you live in a developed country there’s a good chance your taxes have gone up over the past four years.
